brief_summary.textblock:
Although the safety and efficacy of the I gel  in children has been shown in several large
      observational studies, There is no study about comparison of the clinical efficacy between
      I-gel and LMA-Supreme , in particular sizes 1 and 1½. The pediatric i-gel and LMA Supreme
      are  new supraglottic airway device for children. It is made of a soft, gel-like elastomer
      with a noninflatable cuff. Studies about I-gel and LMA Supreme in adults have been
      promising, showing an easy insertion, high airway leak pressures, and low complication rates
      with few postoperative complaints. The aim of this study is to compare clinical performance
      of the pediatric i-gel and LMA Supreme in infants.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Comparison of the Clinical Efficacy Between I-gel and LMA-Supreme, the Two Most Recently Developed Supraglottic Airway Devices, in Infants
clinical_study.condition: Elective Surgery of Short Duration (Less Than 2 hr) Undergoing General Anesthesia Using Supraglottic Airway

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

        1. Infants (0-1 year of age) scheduled for elective surgery of short duration (less than 2
        hr) undergoing general anesthesia using supraglottic airway

        Exclusion Criteria:

        1. Patients with an abnormal airway, reactive airway disease, gastroesophageal reflux
        disease, chronic respiratory disease, or a history of an upper respiratory tract infection
        in the preceding 6-week period

facility.name: Department of Anesthesiology and Pain Medicine Anesthesia and Pain Research Institute Yonsei University College of Medicine

primary_outcome.description: Airway leak pressure was determined by adjusting the expiratory valve of the breathing circle to 30 cmH2O (fixed fresh gas flow 3 L/min) and recording the pressure when equilibrium was reached.
primary_outcome.time_frame: within 5 min of insertion of each device

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject)
